Package moulton.scalable.visuals

Class Animation

  • java.lang.Object
    • moulton.scalable.visuals.Animation
  • public class Animation
extends java.lang.Object
    A class to describe an animation. The animation holds two connected lists, one of BufferedImages, and the other of ints. The images will be the frames in the animation. The list of ints will say how long each frame should be displayed before moving onto the next (measured in milliseconds. Since it is an int-type, the maximum delay per frame is about 2 million seconds. If more time than that needs to be accommodated for, a duplicate frame can be added to the list). The animation needs to be started with startAnimation() and can afterward yield the correct image by a call to getPicture().
    Author:
    Matthew Moulton

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field Description
      protected java.util.ArrayList<java.awt.image.BufferedImage> imageList
      The list of images or frames in the animation.
      protected long lastTime
      The last time in ms that the animation checked its image.
      protected AnimationListener listener
      The listener should be reported to when important events in the animation occur.
      protected int loop
      How many times the animation should loop.
      protected boolean playing
      Whether the animation is running through the frames.
      protected int showIndex
      The index of the lists that the animation is currently showing.
      protected java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> timeList
      The list of times that go along with each image in imageList.

    • Field Detail

      • loop

        protected int loop
        How many times the animation should loop. Default set at 0. Upon reaching the end time for the last frame, the showIndex will return to 0 if loop is greater than 0, then loop will be decremented. A loop value of -1 indicates infinite looping.
        See Also:
        setLoop(int)

      • imageList

        protected java.util.ArrayList<java.awt.image.BufferedImage> imageList
        The list of images or frames in the animation.

      • timeList

        protected java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> timeList
        The list of times that go along with each image in imageList. A measurement of how long (in milliseconds) each frame should be displayed before continuing to the next.

      • listener

        protected AnimationListener listener
        The listener should be reported to when important events in the animation occur.
        See Also:
        setAnimationListener(AnimationListener)

      • showIndex

        protected int showIndex
        The index of the lists that the animation is currently showing. Upon a timeout for the last index, the index will return to 0 if loop is greater than 0. If not, the animation will stop playing (as determined by playing. However, a loop value of -1 is infinite looping.

      • playing

        protected boolean playing
        Whether the animation is running through the frames. If this is false, showIndex will stay constant.
        See Also:
        setAnimationPlay(boolean), startAnimation()

      • lastTime

        protected long lastTime
        The last time in ms that the animation checked its image.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Animation

        public Animation​(int defaultTime,
                 java.awt.image.BufferedImage... frames)
        Creates a new animation with the frames as defined and time values set to match the number of frames. Once this animation is ready to be shown, startAnimation() should be called. Afterwards, getPicture() will return the current frame that should be shown.
        Parameters:
        defaultTime - all time values corresponding to the given frames will be set to this value. They can be altered by using setTimeLimits(int, int...).
        frames - the image frames for this animation.

    • Method Detail

      • setTimeLimits

        public void setTimeLimits​(int startIndex,
                          int... times)
        Alters the time limits for the animation. Each time provided will be set relative to the start index. Therefore, times[0] will be at startIndex in this animation, times[1] will be at startIndex+1 and so forth.
        Parameters:
        startIndex - the index where the first time is defined
        times - the times that should replace the previously saved times. These times will be a measurement in milliseconds that the animation should pause on the corresponding frames before continuing.

      • startAnimation

        public void startAnimation()
        Starts the animation by setting showIndex to 0 and setting the play state to true with setAnimationPlay(boolean). Also saves the current time in milliseconds to know how much time has elapsed once getPicture() is called.

      • setAnimationPlay

        public void setAnimationPlay​(boolean playState)
        Pauses or plays the animation again. If the animation is paused, the timer for the current index will be reset. For example, if the first frame should wait for 1000 ms and 900 ms have elapsed before the animation is paused, once the animation plays again, another 1000 ms needs to elapse before the next frame is shown.
        Parameters:
        playState - whether the animation should be played (true) or paused (false)

      • getPicture

        public java.awt.image.BufferedImage getPicture()
        Updates the animation using System.currentTimeMillis() for the time, changing the index as necessary. After, the current image for the Animation is returned.
        Returns:
        the image that should be shown in the animation right now

      • setLoop

        public void setLoop​(int loop)
        Sets the loop value for the animation.
        Parameters:
        loop - loop

      • setAnimationListener

        public void setAnimationListener​(AnimationListener listener)
        Sets the animation listener that will be notified when important events occur with this animation.
        Parameters:
        listener - the animation listener that will replace listener
